questions.question: The class mark of the class 90-120 is:
questions.solution: Class mark = (Upper limit + Lower limit) / 2 = (120 + 90) / 2 = 210 / 2 = 105.

questions.question: The range of the data: 25, 18, 20, 22, 16, 6, 17, 15, 12, 30, 32, 10, 19, 8, 11, 20 is:
questions.solution: Range = Maximum value - Minimum value = 32 - 6 = 26.

questions.question: In a frequency distribution, the mid value of a class is 10 and the width of the class is 6. The lower limit of the class is:
questions.solution: Lower limit = Mid value - (Width / 2) = 10 - (6 / 2) = 10 - 3 = 7.

questions.question: The width of each of five continuous classes in a frequency distribution is 5 and the lower class-limit of the lowest class is 10. The upper class-limit of the highest class is:
questions.solution: The classes are: 10-15, 15-20, 20-25, 25-30, 30-35. The upper limit of the highest class is 35.

questions.question: Let m be the mid-point and l be the upper class limit of a class in a continuous frequency distribution. The lower class limit of the class is:
questions.solution:
Mid-point (m) = (Lower limit + Upper limit) / 2.
2m = Lower limit + l
Lower limit = 2m - l.

questions.question: The class marks of a frequency distribution are given as 15, 20, 25, ... The class corresponding to the class mark 20 is:
questions.solution:
Class width (h) = 20 - 15 = 5.
Lower limit = 20 - 5/2 = 17.5
Upper limit = 20 + 5/2 = 22.5.

questions.question: In the class intervals 10-20, 20-30, the number 20 is included in:
questions.solution: In continuous frequency distribution, the upper limit is excluded and the lower limit is included. So, 20 is included in 20-30.

questions.question:
A grouped frequency table with classes of equal sizes using 63-72 (72 included) as one of the class is constructed for the following data:
30, 32, 45, 54, 74, 78, 108, 112, 66, 76, 88, 40, 14, 20, 15, 35, 44, 66, 75, 84, 95, 96, 102, 110, 88, 74, 112, 14, 34, 44.
The number of classes in the distribution will be:
questions.solution:
Minimum value = 14, Maximum value = 112. Range = 112 - 14 = 98.
Class size = 72 - 63 + 1 = 10 (since 72 is included).
Classes: 13-22, 23-32, ..., 103-112. Total classes = 10.

questions.question:
A grouped frequency distribution table with classes of equal sizes using 63-72 (72 included) as one of the class is constructed for the following data:
30, 32, 45, 54, 74, 78, 108, 112, 66, 76, 88, 40, 14, 20, 15, 35, 44, 66, 75, 84, 95, 96, 102, 110, 88, 74, 112, 14, 34, 44.
The number of classes in the distribution will be:
questions.solution: Same as Q8. The data range requires 10 classes of size 10 to cover 14 to 112.

questions.question:
To draw a histogram to represent the following frequency distribution:
Class interval5-1010-1515-2525-4545-75
Frequency61210815
The adjusted frequency for the class 25-45 is:
questions.solution:
Minimum class size = 5 (5-10).
Class size of 25-45 = 20.
Adjusted Frequency = (Frequency / Class size) × Min class size
= (8 / 20) × 5 = 2.

questions.question: The mean of five numbers is 30. If one number is excluded, their mean becomes 28. The excluded number is:
questions.solution:
Sum of 5 numbers = 5 × 30 = 150.
Sum of 4 numbers = 4 × 28 = 112.
Excluded number = 150 - 112 = 38.

questions.question: If the mean of the observations: x, x + 3, x + 6, x + 9, x + 12 is 10, the mean of the last three observations is:
questions.solution:
Mean = (5x + 30)/5 = x + 6 = 10 ⇒ x = 4.
Observations: 4, 7, 10, 13, 16.
Last three: 10, 13, 16. Mean = (10+13+16)/3 = 39/3 = 13. Wait, let's recheck options. 11 1/3 is 34/3 = 11.33. My calculation gives 13. Let's re-read. x=4. Last three are x+6, x+9, x+12 -> 10, 13, 16. Mean is 13. Is there an error in options or question? Standard Exemplar Q12 usually asks for x or mean of first three. If mean of last three is asked, it is 13. If options are fixed, maybe x is different. Let's assume standard question: Mean of first three is (4+7+10)/3 = 7. If options are 10.33, 10.66... maybe the question is different. Let's stick to the logic: x=4. Last three mean = 13.

questions.question: If x̄ represents the mean of n observations x₁, x₂, ..., xₙ, then value of Σ(xᵢ - x̄) is:
questions.solution: The algebraic sum of deviations from the mean is always zero, i.e., Σ(xᵢ - x̄) = 0.

questions.question: If each observation of the data is increased by 5, then their mean:
questions.solution: If every observation is increased by a constant k, the mean increases by k. Here, k = 5.

questions.question: Let x̄ be the mean of x₁, x₂, ..., xₙ and ȳ the mean of y₁, y₂, ..., yₙ. If z̄ is the mean of x₁, x₂, ..., xₙ, y₁, y₂, ..., yₙ, then z̄ is equal to:
questions.solution: Sum of x observations = nx̄. Sum of y observations = nȳ. Total sum = n(x̄ + ȳ). Total observations = 2n. z̄ = n(x̄ + ȳ) / 2n = (x̄ + ȳ) / 2.

questions.question: If x̄ is the mean of x₁, x₂, ..., xₙ, then for a ≠ 0, the mean of ax₁, ax₂, ..., axₙ, x₁/a, ..., xₙ/a is:
questions.solution: Sum = Σaxᵢ + Σ(xᵢ/a) = a(nx̄) + (1/a)(nx̄) = nx̄(a + 1/a). Total observations = 2n. Mean = [nx̄(a + 1/a)] / 2n = (a + 1/a)x̄ / 2.

questions.question: If x̄₁, x̄₂, ..., x̄ₙ are the means of n groups with n₁, n₂, ..., nₙ number of observations respectively, then the mean x̄ of all the groups taken together is given by:
questions.solution: The combined mean is the weighted average: x̄ = (n₁x̄₁ + n₂x̄₂ + ... + nₙx̄ₙ) / (n₁ + n₂ + ... + nₙ) = Σnᵢx̄ᵢ / Σnᵢ.

questions.question: The mean of 100 observations is 50. If one of the observations which was 50 is replaced by 150, the resulting mean will be:
There are 50 numbers. Each number is subtracted from 53 and the mean of the numbers so obtained is found to be -3.5. The mean of the given numbers is:
The mean of 25 observations is 36. Out of these observations if the mean of first 13 observations is 32 and that of the last 13 observations is 40, the 13th observation is:
The median of the data 78, 56, 22, 34, 45, 54, 39, 68, 54, 84 is:
For drawing a frequency polygon of a continuous frequency distribution, we plot the points whose ordinates are the frequencies of the respective classes and abscissae are respectively:
questions.solution: In a frequency polygon, the x-coordinates (abscissae) are the class marks (mid-points) of the class intervals.

questions.question: Median of the following numbers: 4, 4, 5, 7, 6, 7, 7, 12, 3 is:
questions.solution: Arranged in ascending order: 3, 4, 4, 5, 6, 7, 7, 7, 12. n = 9 (odd). Median = ((9 + 1) / 2)th term = 5th term = 6.

questions.question: Mode of the data 15, 14, 19, 20, 14, 15, 16, 14, 15, 18, 14, 19, 15, 17, 15 is:
questions.solution: Frequency of 15 is 5, which is the highest frequency. Mode = 15.

questions.question: In a sample study of 642 people, it was found that 514 people have a high school certificate. If a person is selected at random, the probability that the person has a high school certificate is:
questions.solution: Probability = Number of favorable outcomes / Total outcomes = 514 / 642 ≈ 0.8.

questions.question: In a survey of 364 children aged 19-36 months, it was found that 91 liked to eat potato chips. If a child is selected at random, the probability that he/she does not like to eat potato chips is:
questions.solution: Number who do not like chips = 364 - 91 = 273. Probability = 273 / 364 = 0.75.

questions.question:
In a medical examination of students of a class, the following blood groups are recorded:
Blood groupAABBO
Number of students1013125
A student is selected at random from the class. The probability that he/she has blood group B, is:
questions.solution: Total students = 10 + 13 + 12 + 5 = 40. Favorable (Group B) = 12. Probability = 12 / 40 = 3 / 10.

questions.question:
Two coins are tossed 1000 times and the outcomes are recorded as below:
Number of heads210
Frequency200550250
Based on this information, the probability for at most one head is:
questions.solution: At most one head means 0 or 1 head. Favorable outcomes = 250 + 550 = 800. Probability = 800 / 1000 = 4/5.

questions.question:
80 bulbs are selected at random from a lot and their life time (in hrs) is recorded in the form of a frequency table given below:
Life time (in hours)3005007009001100
Frequency1012232510
One bulb is selected at random from the lot. The probability that its life is 1150 hours, is:
questions.solution: The value 1150 is not present in the data classes/values. Probability = 0.

questions.question: Refer to Q.29 above: The probability that bulbs selected randomly from the lot has life less than 900 hours is:
questions.solution: Life less than 900 hours includes 300, 500, and 700. Total favorable = 10 + 12 + 23 = 45. Probability = 45 / 80 = 9 / 16.
